p: Saprolegnia spp. organisms are aquatic oomycetes, known as water molds, which severely impact fish health in aquaculture, fish farms and hobby fish tanks [ 1]. Saprolegniosis occurs mainly in salmonid aquaculture, but also in wild fish [ 2]. These oomycetes can colonize mature and immature stages of fishes, as well as eggs [ 3], causing hyphal growth as cotton-like mycelia on fish body surface and gills. Conversely, fish eggs are killed by hyphae breaking up the chorionic membrane of the eggs, thus provoking an osmotic shock [ 4]. Fishes are more prone to saprolegniosis in the winter, whilst during the rest of the year, when the water temperature is warmer, the disease is usually less frequent [ 5].
